fields.description:
When creating or editing a plan (or a single job), the information for the Git repository is not saved.

There are two entries "Git" in the Repository type dropdown; the first one shows the expected fields for configuration, whereas the second one shows no field at all.

When using the first "Git" entry, entering information into the "Repository URL" and "Branch" fields is required (saving shows an error message if the fields are empty) but the information is not saved upon success.

Therefore, it is impossible to enter Git repository information and thus Git functionality is unavailable.
fields.summary: Git Repository information is not saved to plan/job

fields.description: The HG repository capability key is defined as {{system.hg.executable}} but is {{mercurial.executable}} in the {{elastic-image-capabilities.properties}}. This basically means that HG does not work out of the box for elastic and the user has to configure the image configuration to have this capability manually.
fields.summary: Mercurial Repository capability not correctly set by default on the Default Elastic Configuration

fields.description:
From a comment from a helpful customer on our developer blog:
{quote}
If you remove the Script builder capability from the server
capabilities i cant see a way to add it back again.

I.e. The Script type is not availble from the drop down when you try to
add the builder back again.

Basially i dont want all agents to be able to run script. I only want
some agents to have the script capability, so i removed it as shared
capability but cant add it to a specific agen or even back again as a
shared capability.
{quote}

Someone needs to confirm that this is a bug.
fields.summary: If you remove the Script builder capability from the server capabilities its not possible to add it back

fields.description:
I am developing iPhone apps. Xcode generates an .app bundle, which is a folder with files inside. I set the app as a shared artifact with the copy pattern (*.app/). I used the forward slash at the end to make sure it included all the sub-files and folders. But it did not seem to copy an alias and an executable correctly. All I know is that Xcode code signing scripts are now not working:

error: Codesign check fails : build/AdHoc-iphoneos/Installer.app: a sealed resource is missing or invalid
/Users/william/bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir/INST-ADHOC-PACKAGE/build/AdHoc-iphoneos/Installer.app/CodeResources: resource added

I prepared a screenshot to show the differences.
fields.summary: Artifact Publishing does not copy everything - Blocks Xcode iOS Distribution Script

fields.description:
In the setup wizard there are a few database specific hints. e.g. 

!https://img.skitch.com/20110203-cp4dd534hcjeterarqk11t8ugx.jpg!

If the setting up the db fails the page returns without these hints.  This is particularly annoying because those hints might provide possible reasons why it failed.

fields.summary: TooManyClauses is reported when running reports

fields.description:
Sometimes it is not feasible that the child project build process is build each time a parent build succeeds to build, since the child project build may be costly and only required to build deliverables. 

This could be fixed choosing the build strategy "Manual & dependent builds only" and specified no dependencies. However, from a logical point of view it is not correct, since the child projects do depend on some parent projects. 

What is lacking is a "Manual only" build strategy, that takes specified dependencies into account, e.g. the child build should fail if one of the dependent parent builds have failed etc.
fields.summary: Support "Manual only" build strategy, that takes specified dependencies into account

fields.description: Currently, Bamboo only allows people with global permissions for creation to create and clone a plan. The admin permission at the project level should allow the selected admin to create and clone a plan within their project.

fields.description:
Let's say you get a notification saying you've broken SOMEPROJECT-SOMEPLAN-99.  Here is how to fix it:

# Find out what source repository it's building
# Find out what command it's running to build it

However, unless you're an administrator of the plan/job, you have no way of finding out either of those pieces of information, all you know is that you've broken something, you have no idea what, which is entirely useless.  Finding out what command is run is particularly important, because often there are builds that you break that are running things in weird configurations that you don't normally test, and you need to copy the 10 line long maven command onto your machine in order to run it.
fields.summary: Non plan admins should be able to view plan/job configuration

fields.description: When there are no longer any Plans to be listed below a Project, the Project name still shows up on the User Interface. We should check if there are any Plans to be shown for a particular Project and hide it if there isnt any.

fields.description: Through the Bulk Action admin tool you can update various aspects of the repo (SVN repo URL, SVN credentials, various CVS stuff) but you can't simply tell a Job to inherit the repository details from its Plan.
fields.summary: Add bulk action to be able to set Jobs to use their Plans repository

fields.description:
In order to build a REST client that navigates between resources correctly
As a developer of a REST client
I want a link from the plan resource to the project resource it is a part of


A request to http://localhost:6990/bamboo/rest/api/latest/plan?expand=plans.plan currently responds with a document like this:
{code}
<plans expand="plans">
 <link rel="self" href="http://localhost:6990/bamboo/rest/api/latest/plan"/>
 <plans expand="plan" size="1" max-result="1" start-index="0">
  <plan enabled="false" name="Test Project - Mandatory Values Only" key="TEST-MAND" expand="actions">
  <projectKey>TEST</projectKey>
  <projectName>Test Project</projectName>
  <link rel="self" href="http://localhost:6990/bamboo/rest/api/latest/plan/TEST-MAND"/>
...
  </plan>
 </plans>
</plans>
{code}

This forces the developer of a REST client to assume a URL template to the project resource. Instead, the plan resource should include a link to the project resource (and strictly, the projectKey and projectName elements should be removed as they are redundant. They can stay for informational purposes but should be documented as data that is stale immediately upon transmission)

An updated representation would be (notice the new link element before the projectKey element):
{code}
<plans expand="plans">
 <link rel="self" href="http://localhost:6990/bamboo/rest/api/latest/plan"/>
 <plans expand="plan" size="1" max-result="1" start-index="0">
  <plan enabled="false" name="Test Project - Mandatory Values Only" key="TEST-MAND" expand="actions">
  <link rel="project" href="http://localhost:6990/bamboo/rest/api/latest/project/TEST"/>
  <projectKey>TEST</projectKey>
  <projectName>Test Project</projectName>
  <link rel="self" href="http://localhost:6990/bamboo/rest/api/latest/plan/TEST-MAND"/>
...
  </plan>
 </plans>
</plans>
{code}
fields.summary: REST API: Include link element from plan to project

fields.description:
There appears to be a sequential series of steps to clean the workspace and checkout the source again for builds that force a clean checkout:

28-Jan-2011 14:31:33	Build always requires a clean checkout
28-Jan-2011 14:31:33	Cleaning build directory 'D:\bamboo\1\xml-data\build-dir\FOO-R10WIN-JOB1'
28-Jan-2011 14:35:26	Updating source code to revision: 28764
28-Jan-2011 14:35:26	Working directory 'D:\bamboo\1\xml-data\build-dir\FOO-R10WIN-JOB1' is empty. Checking out SVN URL 'svn+ssh://svn.bar.com/svnroot/baz/foo/trunk'

The problem is that depending on the size of your codebase and the speed of your disk, this cleaning process can take considerable time.

Would it be possible to move the current workspace to a temporary unique name, create the new workspace and start the checkout, and remove the old workspace in the background?

Something like:
  mv WORKSPACE WORKSPACE.3726183763
  rm -rf WORKSPACE.3726183763 &
  mkdir WORKSPACE
  svn co ... 

Rather than
  rm -rf WORKSAPCE/*
  svn co ...

The disk access due to the removal of the workspace would interfere with the checkout, but I'm thinking it wouldn't be as bad as having them run sequentially.
fields.summary: Instant removal of workspaces

fields.description:
The UI for cache cleaning could use some improvements:
- show which agents we schedule deletion on (requires a popup in UI)
- link to documentation - shouldn't we link to documentation in many more places?
- maybe information about the agents where the cache has actually been deleted - this requires synchronous communication to the agents.
fields.summary: Mercurial clean cache UI improvements

fields.description:
Currently (not only in Bamboo 3.0, but in previous versions too) artifact publication first unpacks the message into temp directory and then moves it into artifact directory. This creates unnecessary overhead with large artifacts or artifacts with large amount of files (especially the latter is a big issue with some filesystems).
We should unpack the artifact directly into artifact directory with a temporary name and just rename it as the final step.
fields.summary: Publish artifact directly to artifact directory

fields.description:
This may happen when the user manually deletes the cache directory between change collection & source checkout.
Workaround: wait for next build.

We may detect such case (MissingObjectException), refill the cache and retry the checkout.
We do something similar already when source directory is messed up between checkouts.
fields.summary: Source checkout on local agent should not fail if cache is deleted between change collection & source checkout

fields.description:
If the Global Anonymous Permission to *Access* is disabled, the user still have to login in order to Reset his password.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Disable the *Access* permission for Anonymous Users at the Admin => Global Permissions
2. Logout and try to reset your password using the *Can't access your account?* link.
3. You will receive an email with a link.
4. Click on the link.

Result: You will be redirected to a Login page, not a Reset Password Page. If you login with the correct password the Reset Page is then displayed, but this is not useful when the user forgot his password.
fields.summary: Users can't reset passwords if the Global Anonymous Permission is disabled

fields.description: The Git plugin fetches the correct branch but does not checkout to the branch. This causes issues if the build scripts need to commit changes to Git as it will always go to the master branch. (e.g. build script modifies .csproj assembly infos and attempts to commit the change, it will commit to the incorrect branch). This will also affect tagging as the tag will be on the incorrect branch.
fields.summary: Git plugin does not checkout branch

fields.description:
bamboo.sh failed to start bamboo.   So I tried the java service wrapper instead:

/opt/bamboo/wrapper# ./start-bamboo console
Running Bamboo Continuous Integration Server...
eval: 1: /opt/bamboo/wrapper/wrapper: not found

So I edited the start-bamboo script to output the attempted command and I got:
Running Bamboo Continuous Integration Server...
Command line =  "/opt/bamboo/wrapper/wrapper" "/opt/bamboo/wrapper/../conf/wrapper.conf" wrapper.syslog.ident=bamboo wrapper.pidfile="/opt/bamboo/wrapper/./bamboo.pid"  

eval: 1: /opt/bamboo/wrapper/wrapper: not found

That "not found" is referring to the wrapper.pidfile path.   The "." single dot in the pathname is not correct and at that point the .pid file isn't created.   I modified it to be ".." where the pid file does end up and it still didn't work.
fields.summary: Startup script fails to find bamboo.pid

fields.summary: sometimes, output of the build doesn't appear in Bamboo while it actually rans on the agent

fields.description:
Bamboo 2.7 there is no way to start a build from the configuration pages.  This means that in order to start a build after making a configuration change, I have to navigate to some other page (like plan summary or a recent build) in order to start the build.

Previous versions of bamboo would retain the "Actions" or "Plan Actions" pulldown menu on the configuration pages so you could easily start a build after making a change.

Looking at the screenshots in your call for feedback on bamboo 3.0, it also does not have the ability to start a build from the configuration pages.

http://blogs.atlassian.com/devtools/2011/01/bamboo-30-beta---we-want-your-feedback.html
fields.summary: Ability to start builds from configuration pages in bamboo 2.7+

fields.description: This option allows to display full build history, including NotBuild and InProgress states (excluded by default)
fields.summary: Document includeAllStates REST api option

fields.description:
We need to document that:

During the upgrade to 3.0 there might be an exception while migrating the internal artifact storage if something will go wrong: https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-2404. 
We've just made this upgrade task restartable, so it will pick up where it left after Bamboo will be restarted. However if that message will be displayed by Bamboo:
{noformat}
Unable to move DIRECTORY_NAME_A -> DIRECTORY_NAME_B, destination directory already exists. This might indicate interrupted upgrade process. To continue upgrade, move directory manually.
{noformat}
it means that some directory was partially moved and user must complete the move manually.
fields.summary: Update doc on the upgrade process for 3.0
(Git repo) Successive code retrievals should use non-shallow fetches

fields.description:
1) Plan A is created, initial collectChangeset
2) should do shallowClone to the R1 revision. (it should contain let's say: R0-R1 revisions, R0 is shallow)
3) repository grow up to R2-R3-R4-R5, let's assume Plan A is not collecting those changes yet
4) Plan B is created, initial collectChangeset
5) cache repository should fetch changesets since Plan A initial changesCollection, i.e it should contain R0-R1-R2-R3-R4-R5
6a) Plan A is checking the changes... it should trigger the build listing R2-R3-R4-R5 changelist.
6b) but I'm worried it might fail because local repo might have missing R2-R3 due to R4 being shallow
fields.summary: Git repo initial cache retrieval (the shallow one) should work properly between multiple plans using the same repo.
Plans don't properly check repository configuration changes

fields.description:
Thanks for trying out the Bamboo 3.0 Beta version!

We would love to hear your feedback and comments about this release. To keep the discussion centralized, feel free to comment on this issue with your feedback.

[Bamboo 3.0 beta download|http://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/BambooEAPDownloads.jspa]
fields.summary: Bamboo 3.0 Beta Feedback

fields.description:
We are migrating our builds from Hudson and are missing a feature: *Parametrized build* (i.e the ability to configure some build parameters with a web form when starting the Build. See: http://wiki.hudson-ci.org/display/HUDSON/Parameterized+Build)

We feel that configuring the build job every time we want to perform a release is tedious and error prone. Having such a feature is key to the adoption of Bamboo as a Continuous integration server.

We've tried to install the Release management plugin from Sysbliss, but it's not compatible with Bamboo 2.7.
fields.summary: Allow a build job to be parametrized in order to simplify release management
Support checking out a git tag, not just branch
LocalAgentManager is not available to plugins

fields.description: Especially on the dashboard pages.  There seems to be some code lying around for this, but it doesn't seem to work.
fields.summary: Favouriting on dashboard without refresh

fields.description: We create a ChainExecution object, pass it to the pre-chain-plugins to do their thing, then recreate when we actually run the build.  Whilst at the moment the effects are minimal (as the ChainExecution is mostly just a wrapper around an object which is passed around), it could cause us some pain in the future.  Also it does limit slightly what the plugins can do.
fields.summary: ChainExecution passed to plugins is no the object that is used when building

fields.description: Any exceptions thrown from plugins are ignored.  This could be disastrous (the exceptions are there for a reason).  We either need to propagate these exceptions, or come up with another way for plugins to error out the build.
fields.summary: Plugin Exceptions ignored during chain execution

fields.description: The customDataMap is only persisted to the db when the result is actually created at the beginning of the build. Plugins may have added to this throughout the build, so it needs to be persisted at the end of the build as well.
fields.summary: chain's CurrentBuildResult.customDataMap not saved at the end of the build
Should be able to stop the chain inside of chain and build plugin points.
Refactor maven dependencies table so it is reusable.

fields.description:
If your cron expression fails for some reason (when submitting the entire form), you get a red error message.  You then click on the pencil, edit the cron expression and click done.  The red message is still and looks like it applying to the new value.  The errors should be removed when the dialog returns.

This is pretty low priority - validation should occur in the dialog itself, so getting errors on the form should be a rare occurance.
fields.summary: Cron Builder should clear validation errors on return from dialog

fields.description:
We should have shallow clones used by default for git repositories.

However, some builds may require access to history data. To cater for this we should have a checkbox for git repositories in Bamboo as to whether shallow clones should be used.

Shallow clones should be used by default.
fields.summary: Add configuration option to enable or disable shallow clones for git to the git repository in Bamboo

fields.description: See [BSP-3968|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-3968].  When the main purpose of a build stage is to produce an artifact such as a war file, then the failure of the build stage to produce said artifact should be considered a failure.  Hence, please provide the option to designate whether or not a failure of the Artifact Copier to actually copy the desired derivative is to be considered a build failure.
fields.summary: Add Option to Conditionally Fail Build When Artifact Copy Can't Find Derivative to Copy
